qas.question: Prior to what age did France have a history with the mandolin?
Where in France did the mandolinists play?
When did the mandolinists stop playing in Paris?
Who were the players and composers during this time?

answers.text: Giovanni Fouchetti, Eduardo Mezzacapo, Gabriele Leon, and Gervasio

qas.question: What years was considered the Golden Age of Mandolins?
Prior to what age did Italy have a history with the mandolin?
Where in Italy did the mandolinists play?
When did the mandolinists start playing in Paris?

plausible_answers.text: Giovanni Fouchetti, Eduardo Mezzacapo, Gabriele Leon, and Gervasio

qas.question: Who weren't the players and composers during this time?
What years weren't considered the Golden Age of Mandolins?

context: <b5_0>Prior to the <a0_0>Golden Age<b5_0/> of Mandolins<a0_0/>, France had a history with the mandolin, with mandolinists playing in <a1_0><b6_0>Paris<b6_0/><a1_0/> until the <a2_0><b7_0>Napoleonic Wars<b7_0/>.<a2_0/> The players, teachers and composers included <a3_0><b8_0>Giovanni Fouchetti, Eduardo Mezzacapo, Gabriele Leon, and Gervasio<b8_0/><a3_0/>. During the Golden age itself (<a4_0><b9_0>1880s-1920s<b9_0/><a4_0/>), the mandolin had a strong presence in France. Prominent mandolin players or composers included Jules Cottin and his sister Madeleine Cottin, Jean Pietrapertosa, and Edgar Bara. Paris had dozens of "estudiantina" mandolin orchestras in the early 1900s. Mandolin magazines included L'Estudiantina, Le Plectre, École de la mandolie.
